name: Round Rock
description: Round Rock is the largest city in Williamson County and one of the most convenient places for seniors to call home. The city offers a strong network of healthcare providers, including Baylor Scott & White and Ascension Seton, both within easy reach. Older adults who enjoy staying active will find plenty to do at the Clay Madsen Recreation Center, which hosts fitness classes, swimming, and social groups designed for adults 55 and older. Old Settlers Park stretches across 570 acres with paved walking trails, fishing ponds, and shaded picnic areas that are popular with morning walking groups. The Dell Diamond area has become a hub for dining and entertainment, and catching a Round Rock Express game is a favorite local outing. Neighborhoods like Brushy Creek and Behrens Ranch offer quiet, well-maintained streets with sidewalks and proximity to shopping. The Round Rock Senior Center on East Main Street provides daily programming, from card games to health screenings. With H-E-B, Costco, and major retailers nearby, everyday errands are simple. Round Rock strikes a balance between big-city amenities and a genuine small-town feel that keeps long-time residents rooted here.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Round Rock, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Find trusted senior services, healthcare, activities, and resources in Round Rock, TX. Complete guide for 55+ residents in Williamson County.

name: Georgetown
description: Georgetown is widely considered the senior-living capital of Williamson County, thanks in large part to Sun City Texas, one of the largest active-adult communities in the state with over 9,000 homes. But Georgetown has much more to offer beyond Sun City. The historic downtown square is one of the most beautifully preserved in Texas, lined with locally owned shops, cafes, and the Georgetown Public Library. The San Gabriel River runs through town and feeds the popular Blue Hole swimming area and miles of walking trails along the river corridor. Seniors who value culture will enjoy regular events at the Palace Theatre and seasonal markets on the square. St. David's Georgetown Hospital and Georgetown Health Foundation provide solid healthcare infrastructure. The Georgetown Senior Activity Center on Rock Street offers classes in everything from watercolor painting to line dancing. Neighborhoods like Berry Creek and Cimarron Hills provide resort-style living with golf courses and clubhouses. Georgetown was named the most beautiful town square in Texas, and residents take real pride in keeping it that way. The pace of life here is calm but never boring, with enough going on to keep any week full.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Georgetown, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Explore senior services, 55+ communities, healthcare, and activities in Georgetown, TX. Your guide to senior living in Williamson County.

name: Cedar Park
description: Cedar Park sits on the southwestern edge of Williamson County and offers seniors a comfortable suburban lifestyle with easy access to Austin. The H-E-B Center at Cedar Park hosts concerts, hockey games, and community events year-round, giving residents entertainment without a long drive. Cedar Park's trail system is a standout feature, with the Brushy Creek Regional Trail connecting neighborhoods across miles of paved, shaded pathways perfect for walking, cycling, or simply enjoying the outdoors. The Cedar Park Recreation Center onQuest Boulevard offers fitness programs, a lap pool, and senior-specific classes. Healthcare access is strong with Cedar Park Regional Medical Center and numerous specialty clinics along the US-183A corridor. For everyday needs, the 1890 Ranch shopping center and Lakeline Mall area provide groceries, dining, and services all within a short drive. The Twin Lakes YMCA is another popular gathering spot for older adults looking for both exercise and community. Neighborhoods like Ranch at Brushy Creek and Buttercup Creek are known for their well-kept common areas, community pools, and friendly neighbors. Cedar Park is a practical choice for seniors who want a quieter setting without giving up urban conveniences.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Cedar Park, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Discover senior services, recreation, healthcare, and community resources in Cedar Park, TX. A guide for 55+ residents in Williamson County.

name: Leander
description: Leander has been one of the fastest-growing cities in the country over the past decade, and seniors moving here are discovering a community that blends Hill Country scenery with modern infrastructure. The Capital Metro Red Line connects Leander to downtown Austin, making it one of the few Williamson County cities with commuter rail access, a real advantage for seniors who prefer not to drive into the city. The Leander Public Library on Bagdad Road is a bright, modern facility that hosts book clubs, technology classes, and community gatherings. Crystal Falls Golf Club and the surrounding neighborhood offer resort-quality living with rolling terrain and mature trees. Divine Mercy Catholic Church and Leander Church of Christ are just two examples of the active faith community here. Mason Creek Park and Benbrook Ranch Park provide open green spaces with playgrounds for visiting grandchildren and trails for daily walks. New retail centers along US-183 have brought H-E-B, restaurants, and medical offices closer to residential areas. While Leander is still building out some of its senior-specific programming, the city government has shown a commitment to accommodating its growing older adult population. The combination of affordable housing, natural beauty, and improving amenities makes Leander worth a close look.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Leander, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Find senior services, transit options, recreation, and resources in Leander, TX. Guide for 55+ adults in Williamson County.

name: Pflugerville
description: Pflugerville is one of the most diverse communities in Williamson County, and that diversity shows up in its food, its festivals, and its neighborhoods. Lake Pflugerville is the centerpiece of outdoor life here, offering a three-mile trail loop around the lake that is flat, paved, and popular with morning walkers and evening strollers alike. The Pflugerville Recreation Center on Immanuel Road runs fitness classes, social events, and wellness programs, many designed with older adults in mind. Deutschen Pfest, the city's annual German heritage festival, is a beloved tradition that draws the whole community together each spring. Healthcare options are strong, with Ascension Seton and St. David's facilities accessible along the I-35 corridor. The Pflugerville Public Library on 10th Street is a welcoming space that offers regular programming including tech help sessions and community speaker events. Neighborhoods like Blackhawk, Falcon Pointe, and Highland Park are established and well-maintained, with mature landscaping and quiet streets. Shopping and dining are concentrated along FM 685 and Grand Avenue Parkway, keeping daily errands close to home. Pflugerville combines a small-town identity with the cultural richness of a growing, welcoming community.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Pflugerville, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Explore senior services, lake activities, healthcare, and community resources in Pflugerville, TX. Guide for 55+ residents in Williamson County.

name: Hutto
description: Hutto has grown significantly in recent years but still holds on to the small-town character that long-time residents love. The city's mascot is the hippo, a nod to a quirky local legend, and you will spot hippo statues and murals throughout town. Downtown Hutto along East Street has a charming strip of local businesses, antique shops, and restaurants that invite a leisurely afternoon. Fritz Park is the main recreation hub, with ball fields, a playground, and open green space for community events. The Hutto Public Library offers book clubs, crafting sessions, and digital literacy workshops that draw a regular group of older adults. Co-Op District, a redevelopment of the old Hutto Co-Op property, is bringing new dining and retail options to the heart of town. Healthcare access is improving as medical clinics expand along US-79 and the Hutto corridor connecting to Round Rock hospitals. Star Ranch and Riverwalk are popular residential neighborhoods with newer homes, wide sidewalks, and community amenity centers. The Hutto Senior Activity program, run through the parks department, organizes monthly lunches and seasonal outings. For seniors looking for affordability and a genuine sense of community, Hutto delivers.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Hutto, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Find senior services, community activities, and resources in Hutto, TX. A growing Williamson County city with small-town charm for 55+ residents.

name: Taylor
description: Taylor is a historic railroad town on the eastern edge of Williamson County that has been getting renewed attention thanks to the massive Samsung semiconductor facility being built nearby. For seniors, Taylor offers something increasingly rare: an authentic small-town Texas downtown with real character. Main Street is lined with murals, antique stores, and locally owned restaurants, including Louie Mueller Barbecue, which has been serving brisket since 1949. The Taylor Public Library hosts regular events and provides a cozy space for reading and socializing. Murphy Park is the city's main green space, with walking paths, picnic pavilions, and a community pool. Heritage Square downtown hosts seasonal markets and live music. Healthcare is available locally through Baylor Scott & White clinics, with larger hospital facilities a short drive west in Round Rock. The Taylor Senior Citizens Center on Talbot Street is a gathering place for card games, potluck lunches, and holiday celebrations. Faith communities play a strong role here, with churches of every denomination active in outreach and fellowship. Housing in Taylor remains more affordable than much of Williamson County, and the slower pace of life appeals to those who want a break from suburban sprawl. With Samsung's investment bringing new infrastructure and jobs, Taylor is poised for thoughtful growth while preserving the heritage that makes it special.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Taylor, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Discover senior services, historic charm, and community resources in Taylor, TX. A Williamson County town with affordable living for 55+ residents.

name: Liberty Hill
description: Liberty Hill sits in the western Hill Country portion of Williamson County and has experienced rapid growth while maintaining its rural roots. The landscape here is noticeably different from the eastern part of the county, with rolling limestone hills, live oak trees, and wide-open ranch land that gives every drive a scenic quality. Downtown Liberty Hill along State Highway 29 has a handful of local restaurants, a feed store, and a growing number of small businesses that cater to the expanding population. The Liberty Hill Festival, held each fall, brings together the community with live music, vendors, and old-fashioned fun. For seniors, the appeal of Liberty Hill is the space and the quiet. Master-planned communities like Santa Rita Ranch and Rio Ancho offer newer homes with Hill Country views and neighborhood amenity centers with pools and fitness rooms. The South Fork San Gabriel River runs through the area, providing opportunities for fishing and nature walks. Healthcare requires a short drive to Cedar Park or Georgetown, which is the main trade-off for living in a more rural setting. Faith communities are a central part of life here, and neighbors tend to know each other by name. Liberty Hill is ideal for seniors who want acreage, fresh air, and a close-knit community.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Liberty Hill, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Find senior resources and community information in Liberty Hill, TX. Hill Country living for 55+ adults in western Williamson County.

name: Jarrell
description: Jarrell is a small but growing community in northern Williamson County, positioned along the I-35 corridor between Georgetown and Temple. For seniors who prefer a quieter, more affordable lifestyle while staying connected to bigger-city amenities, Jarrell is worth considering. The town has seen new residential development in recent years, with subdivisions like Sonterra and Sundance bringing modern, single-story homes to market at price points well below the county average. Jarrell Community Park on 3rd Street is a gathering spot for families and hosts the occasional community cookout or holiday event. The Jarrell Public Library, though small, provides internet access, reading programs, and a welcoming atmosphere for daily visitors. For groceries and medical appointments, Georgetown is about fifteen minutes south on I-35, and Round Rock is just a bit further. Faith communities in Jarrell, including Jarrell United Methodist Church and First Baptist Church, are active in supporting older residents through fellowship meals and transportation assistance. The pace of life here is genuinely slow, and that is exactly what many residents are looking for. As Williamson County continues to grow northward, Jarrell is positioned to gain more services and infrastructure while still offering the breathing room of a small town.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Jarrell, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Explore senior resources and community life in Jarrell, TX. Affordable small-town living for 55+ adults in northern Williamson County.

name: Florence
description: Florence is the most rural community on our list, tucked into the northwestern corner of Williamson County where the land opens up into cattle ranches and wide Texas sky. Life here moves at its own pace, and that is the whole point. Florence is the kind of place where you wave at every truck that passes and where the local volunteer fire department hosts the best pancake breakfast in the county. The Florence Lions Club and local churches are the backbone of community life, organizing holiday dinners, domino nights, and check-in visits for older neighbors who live alone. The town sits along FM 487 and FM 970, with a small cluster of businesses including a gas station, a post office, and a few family-run shops. The surrounding countryside is beautiful, with wildflower-covered fields in spring and dramatic sunsets year-round. Lake Georgetown and the Good Water Trail are about twenty minutes south, providing excellent hiking and fishing. Medical services require a drive to Georgetown or Temple, which is the most significant consideration for seniors thinking about Florence. Internet and cell service can be spotty in some areas. But for those who value independence, open land, and a true rural lifestyle, Florence offers a way of life that is becoming harder to find. The community is small enough that everyone looks out for each other, and that kind of neighborly care means a great deal.
seoTitle: Senior Services in Florence, TX | WilCo Seniors
metaDescription: Learn about senior resources and rural community life in Florence, TX. Close-knit living for 55+ adults in northwestern Williamson County.
